In India, the President of India presides over the joint sessions of Parliament. The President is the head of the state and the ceremonial head of the government, and is elected by the members of the Electoral College, which consists of the elected members of both houses of Parliament and the state legislatures.

When a joint session of Parliament is convened, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha (the lower house of Parliament) and the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of Parliament) jointly preside over the proceedings. However, in the event of a tie, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha has the casting vote.

The joint session of Parliament is convened by the President under Article 108 of the Constitution, which states that the President may summon a joint session of both houses of Parliament to consider a bill or any other matter that he thinks is of national importance. The President may also address the joint session and give his views on the matter being considered.

During the joint session, the members of both houses of Parliament sit together in the Central Hall of Parliament House, and the proceedings are conducted by the Speaker of the Lok Sabha. The members of the Rajya Sabha also participate in the proceedings, but they do not have the power to vote. The joint session is usually convened to pass important legislation or to discuss matters of national importance.

joint session of both houses of Parliament
any other matter of national importance
members of both houses of Parliament
reference: The Parliament of India is bicameral . Concurrence of both houses are required to pass any bill . However , the authors of the Constitution of India visualised situations of deadlock between the upper house i.e. Rajya Sabha and the lower house i.e. Lok Sabha . Therefore , the Constitution of India provides for Joint sittings of both the Houses to break this deadlock . The joint sitting of the Parliament is called by the President and is presided over by the Speaker or , in his absence , by the Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha or in his absence , the Deputy - Chairman of the Rajya Sabha . If any of the above officers are not present then any other member of the Parliament can preside by consensus of both the House .

The raid on the Harpers Ferry Arsenal was led by John Brown, a prominent abolitionist who believed that violence was necessary to end slavery. Brown and his followers, including several of his sons, launched the raid on October 16, 1859, with the goal of seizing the federal armory and distributing weapons to local slaves, who would then rise up and overthrow their masters.

The raid was not successful, and Brown and his men were quickly surrounded by a company of U.S. Marines led by Colonel Robert E. Lee, who had been sent to suppress the uprising. After a brief battle, Brown and his surviving followers were captured and later executed for treason, conspiracy, and murder.

The raid on Harpers Ferry was a significant event in the lead-up to the Civil War, as it heightened tensions between abolitionists and pro-slavery forces and helped to galvanize public opinion against slavery. Brown's actions were seen by many as a heroic attempt to end the evil of slavery, and he became a martyr for the abolitionist cause.

Brown 's party of 22 was defeated by a company of U.S. Marines , led by First Lieutenant Israel Greene . Colonel Robert E. Lee was in overall command of the operation to retake the arsenal . John Brown had originally asked Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglass , both of whom he had met in his transformative years as an abolitionist in Springfield , Massachusetts , to join him in his raid , but Tubman was prevented by illness and Douglass declined , as he believed Brown 's plan would fail .

The Wave Hill Walk-Off, also known as the Gurindji Strike, ended in 1975. The walk-off began in 1966, when the Gurindji people, led by Vincent Lingiari, left their jobs on the Wave Hill cattle station in the Northern Territory to protest against poor working conditions and low wages. They set up a camp at Daguragu, near the station, and remained there for nine years, despite facing harassment and intimidation from the station owners and the government.

In 1975, the Australian government, led by Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, negotiated a settlement with the Gurindji people, which included the granting of land rights to the Gurindji people over part of the Wave Hill station. The Gurindji people were also given control over the Daguragu camp, which became a Aboriginal-owned and run community.

The Wave Hill Walk-Off was a significant event in the history of Indigenous rights in Australia, and it helped to raise awareness of the struggles faced by Aboriginal people in the country. It also contributed to the establishment of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in 1976, which allowed Indigenous Australians to claim rights to their traditional lands.

The 10 shilling note was first introduced in 1793, and it remained in circulation until 1971, when it was withdrawn and replaced by the decimal pound.

The last 10 shilling note was issued in 1969, and it featured a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II on the obverse and a vignette of the Old Royal Naval College in Greenwich on the reverse.

After decimalization, the 10 shilling note was converted to a 50 pence coin, which was introduced in 1971. The 50 pence coin was initially equivalent to 10 shillings, but its value has since increased due to inflation.

In the United States Senate, the Vice President of the United States serves as the President of the Senate and casts the tie-breaking vote in the event of a tie. This is a constitutional provision that is outlined in Article I, Section 3, Clause 4 of the United States Constitution, which states:

"The Vice President of the United States shall be President of the Senate, but shall have no Vote, unless they be equally divided."

This means that if there is a tie vote in the Senate, the Vice President can cast a vote to break the tie. The Vice President's vote is not automatic, however, and they must choose to vote in order to break the tie. If the Vice President is not present or unable to vote, the tie remains unbroken.

It's worth noting that the Vice President's role in breaking ties in the Senate is a rare occurrence. In most cases, the Senate is able to reach a majority vote without the need for the Vice President's intervention. However, in the event of a tie, the Vice President's vote can be crucial in determining the outcome of a vote.

Ambulatory refers to the ability of a patient to walk or move around freely, without the need for bed rest or hospitalization. In healthcare, the term "ambulatory care" refers to medical services or procedures that are performed on an outpatient basis, meaning the patient does not need to stay overnight in a hospital or clinic.

Ambulatory care can include a wide range of services, such as:

1. Doctor's offices: Primary care physicians, specialists, and other healthcare providers who see patients in their offices for routine check-ups, consultations, and treatments.
2. Clinics: Specialized clinics that provide focused care for specific conditions or populations, such as pediatric clinics, cancer clinics, or geriatric clinics.
3. Urgent care centers: Facilities that provide immediate medical attention for non-life-threatening conditions, such as sprains, strains, and minor injuries.
4. Surgical centers: Facilities that provide same-day surgical procedures, such as cataract surgery, endoscopies, and colonoscopies.
5. Rehabilitation centers: Facilities that provide physical therapy, occupational therapy, and other forms of rehabilitation for patients recovering from injuries, illnesses, or surgery.

The Nobel Peace Prize is considered one of the most prestigious awards in the world, and it is awarded annually to individuals or organizations who have made outstanding contributions to peace and conflict resolution. reference: Brain tissue consumes a large amount of energy in proportion to its volume , so large brains place severe metabolic demands on animals . The need to limit body weight in order , for example , to fly , has apparently led to selection for a reduction of brain size in some species , such as bats . Most of the brain 's energy consumption goes into sustaining the electric charge ( membrane potential ) of neurons . Most vertebrate species devote between 2 % and 8 % of basal metabolism to the brain . In primates , however , the percentage is much higher -- in humans it rises to 20 -- 25 % . The energy consumption of the brain does not vary greatly over time , but active regions of the cerebral cortex consume somewhat more energy than inactive regions ; this forms the basis for the functional brain imaging methods PET , fMRI , and NIRS . The brain typically gets most of its energy from oxygen - dependent metabolism of glucose ( i.e. , blood sugar ) , but ketones provide a major alternative source , together with contributions from medium chain fatty acids ( caprylic and heptanoic acids ) , lactate , acetate , and possibly amino acids .

The group that officially elects the President of the United States is the Electoral College. The Electoral College is a process established by the Founding Fathers in the Constitution, where each state is allocated a certain number of electoral votes based on its population, and the candidate who receives the majority of the electoral votes, at least 270 out of 538, wins the presidency.

The Electoral College consists of 538 electors, with each state having a number of electors equal to its number of members in the House of Representatives plus its number of Senators. The District of Columbia also has three electors.

During a presidential election, voters cast ballots for a candidate, but they are actually voting for a slate of electors who have pledged to support that candidate. These electors then meet in their respective state capitals to cast their electoral votes for president and vice president. The candidate who receives the majority of the electoral votes wins the presidency.

The Electoral College system has been the subject of controversy and criticism over the years, with some arguing that it is undemocratic and that it can lead to a candidate winning the presidency without receiving the most popular votes. However, others argue that the Electoral College ensures that smaller states have a voice in the election process and prevents larger states from dominating the outcome.

reference: The election of President and Vice President of the United States is an indirect election in which citizens of the United States who are registered to vote in one of the 50 U.S. states or in Washington , D.C. cast ballots not directly for those offices , but instead for members of the U.S. Electoral College , known as electors . These electors then in turn cast direct votes , known as electoral votes , for President , and for Vice President . The candidate who receives an absolute majority of electoral votes ( at least 270 out of a total of 538 , since the Twenty - Third Amendment granting voting rights to citizens of Washington , D.C. ) is then elected to that office . If no candidate receives an absolute majority of the votes for President , the House of Representatives chooses the winner ; if no one receives an absolute majority of the votes for Vice President , then the Senate chooses the winner .

The joint between the coxal bone of the pelvis and the sacrum is called the sacroiliac joint (SI joint). It is a synovial joint that connects the auricular surface of the sacrum and the acetabulum of the coxal bone (hip bone).

The SI joint is a gliding joint, which means that it allows for movement in multiple planes, including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, and circumduction. The joint is surrounded by a capsule and ligaments that provide stability and support.

The SI joint plays a crucial role in the transmission of forces between the pelvis and the lower extremities. It helps to absorb shock and distribute pressure during weight-bearing activities, such as walking, running, and jumping. The joint also helps to maintain proper alignment of the pelvis and lower extremities, which is essential for proper gait and balance.

Dysfunction or inflammation of the SI joint can cause pain and discomfort in the lower back, hips, and legs. This condition is known as sacroiliac joint dysfunction or SI joint syndrome. Treatment options for SI joint dysfunction include physical therapy, chiropractic care, and in some cases, surgery.
